metadata.description: Comprehensive lesson content and learning objectives for AI tutor

python-basics-variables.title: Python Basics: Variables and Input/Output
learningObjectives: Understand variables as memory containers with real-world analogies
Apply the ASK → STORE → THINK → RESPOND pattern

keyAnalogies.variables: Phone contacts - each contact has a name (label) and stores information
keyAnalogies.input: Drive-thru ordering - asking questions and waiting for responses
keyAnalogies.output: Text messaging - sending responses back to users

interactiveConcepts.explanation: Creating labeled storage boxes in computer memory
scaffoldedHints: Think of variables like labeled boxes - you need to create the box first
The equals sign (=) puts something INTO the variable, it doesn't check if they're equal

interactiveConcepts.explanation: How programs ask questions and wait for user responses
commonMistakes: Not storing input in a variable
scaffoldedHints: input() always returns text (strings), even if user types numbers
Don't forget to store the result: name = input('Question')
The text inside input() is what the user sees as a prompt

interactiveConcepts.explanation: Converting between text and numbers for calculations
commonMistakes: Trying to do math with strings
scaffoldedHints: Use int() to convert text to whole numbers: age = int(input('Age: '))
Use float() for decimal numbers: price = float(input('Price: '))
Remember: input() always gives you text first!

python-magic-8-ball.title: Project: Magic 8-Ball Game
learningObjectives: Build a complete interactive Python project
Use lists to store multiple options
Implement random selection for game mechanics
Create user-friendly program flow with loops

keyAnalogies.lists: Photo gallery on your phone - ordered collection of items you can access by position
keyAnalogies.randomChoice: Shuffling a deck of cards - computer picks one at random
keyAnalogies.loops: Instagram feed refresh - keeps asking 'want to see more?' until you say stop

projectStages.description: Build list with positive, negative, and neutral responses
hints: Start with at least 8 different responses
Include variety for realistic magic 8-ball experience
Don't forget 'import random' at the top
